{"step_by_step_thinking": "Chronic renal failure, also known as chronic kidney disease, is characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. Let's analyze each statement: a) Urine output is more than 3 litres per day - This is not necessarily true. In the early stages of chronic kidney disease, urine output may remain normal. As the disease progresses, urine output can decrease significantly. b) Urine concentration is decreased - This is true. As the kidneys lose their ability to concentrate urine, the urine becomes more diluted. c) Sodium conservation is poor - This is also true. The kidneys play a crucial role in maintaining sodium balance in the body. In chronic kidney disease, the ability of the kidneys to conserve sodium is impaired. d) Polycythemia is present - This is not true. Polycythemia refers to an increased number of red blood cells. In chronic kidney disease, there is usually anemia, or a decreased number of red blood cells, due to decreased production of erythropoietin, a hormone that stimulates red blood cell production.", "answer_choice": "C. bc"}
